itemDescription: Solomon Island social worker and women's rights activist

wikipedia_page.main: Merle Aqorau, MBE (born 1939) is a Solomon Islander and social worker who was instrumental in the development of the women's movement in the Solomon Islands. Engaged as a social welfare officer, she established women's clubs in various locations throughout Melanesia, founded a YWCA training centre to assist young women in continuing their education and worked as the regional secretary of the United Church Women's  Fellowship (UCWF). Her pioneering service to women in the Solomon Islands was recognised, when she was awarded an MBE in the Order of the British Empire in 2016.

response: Aqorau then, studied at the University of Canterbury and in 1956 became the first Solomon Islander to graduate with a bachelor's degree. Sam Alasia (1989) Ples Blong Iumi: Solomon Islands, the Past Four Thousand Years p104 He remained at the university until the following year to earn a master's degree.Islander Graduates from NZ University Pacific Islands Monthly, January 1957, p35 He married Merle Aqorau in 1958, later adopting her surname.At 77, Aqorau gets her MBE Solomon Star, 13 June 2016 The two relocated to England, where he spent a year at the University of Cambridge studying colonial administration, also visiting local councils, while his wife studied domestic science in London. Mr. Francis Talasasa Pacific Islands Monthly, April 1959, p9 After returning to the Solomon Islands, he became a Cadet Administrative Officer in Malaita in 1959. He was soon promoted to Deputy Commissioner, the first Solomon Islander to reach such a position. In June 1962, he was also the first Solomon Islander to be appointed as a magistrate.
